newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia prepares broad-based broadcasting law.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia prepares broad-based broadcasting law.

text.p: Indonesia is expected to pass a broadcasting bill this month that could have a far-reaching impact on its radio, television and advertising industries and limit foreign participation, an MP said on Tuesday.

"We are now in the final stage of discussing the draft bill which was submitted by the government in March this year," Abu Hasan Sazili, chairman of the parliamentary committee on the broadcasting bill, told Reuters.
Under Indonesia's political system, parliament has the right to make changes to a bill submitted by the government, but any alterations are usually insignificant.
"We expect to pass it at our meeting on October 17 and then submit it back to the government for signing by President Suharto," Sazili said of the draft bill.
He noted the country had no previous broadcasting law.
"The broadcasting law is likely to have a broad-based impact, not just on the traditional media like (television), but also on new technology like the internet," Sazili said.
If the internet were used to broadcast directly, he explained, it would fall under the bill.
The chairman said the legislation would sharply limit foreign participation in broadcasting and advertising in the medium.
"Broadcasting is a very sensitive industry that could have significant impact, especially on our social and political values. That's why their (foreign) roles must be limited," he said.
Sazili said even the physical background of an advertisement should be Indonesian.
The draft bill stipulated that broadcast advertising should be produced by firms licensed by the government, using Indonesian scenery and Indonesian artists and Indonesian production partners.
He said that advertisements by foreign firms, such as Philip Morris Companies Inc's Marlboro cigarette advertisement which features cowboys, were likely to be affected.
Under the draft bill, private broadcasting firms will be banned from receiving foreign financial support. Technical and other assistance would be allowed only under government permits.
The bill, however, could pave the way for the country's largest television station, PT Bimantara Citra's Rajawali Citra Televisi Indonesia (RCTI), to float its shares on the local stock exchanges.

Bimantara's RCTI, controlled by President Suharto's son Bambang Trihatmojo, has wanted to list its shares on local exchanges for several years, but current regulations do not allow this, media analysts say.
Under the proposed bill, broadcasting firms would be able to raise funds from the capital market after obtaining government permission.
But RCTI and four other private stations may face stiff competition for advertising revenue, as the draft bill would allow state-owned Televisi Republik Indonesia (TVRI) to carry advertising.
TVRI is the oldest station and has a larger network and more extensive coverage than other stations.
The draft bill proposes penalties for violations of regulations of up to one billion rupiah ($430,000) and/or a prison term of up to 10 years.
